articles.headline: ‘The New Berlin Wall’: Why Ukraine Is Central to the Scandal
articles.snippet: Caught between East and West, it is a place that attracts adventurers and carpetbaggers, who return home with “legacies, memories and skeletons for their closets.”
articles.abstract: Caught between East and West, it is a place that attracts adventurers and carpetbaggers, who return home with “legacies, memories and skeletons for their closets.”
articles.lead_paragraph: IVANO-FRANKIVSK, Ukraine — His voice crackling over what he complained was a “terrible” sound system, Donald J. Trump in September 2015 heaped praise on the oligarch who had invited him to speak by video link from New York to a conference in Kiev, the capital of Ukraine.

articles.headline: $129 Billion Puerto Rico Bankruptcy Plan Could Be Model for States
articles.snippet: An oversight board proposed a way to deal with the island’s debt crisis, which took an act of Congress and lots of wrangling.
articles.abstract: An oversight board proposed a way to deal with the island’s debt crisis, which took an act of Congress and lots of wrangling.
articles.lead_paragraph: After years of wrangling with its creditors, Puerto Rico disclosed a plan Friday for resolving the biggest governmental bankruptcy in United States history, by cutting $129 billion in debts to about $86 billion — a reduction of 33 percent.
articles.byline: By Mary Williams Walsh and Karl Russell

articles.headline: House Democrats Issue First Subpoena in Impeachment Inquiry
articles.snippet: Three committee chairmen issued the first subpoena in the impeachment inquiry into President Trump, seeking documents and witnesses regarding his dealings with Ukraine.
articles.abstract: Three committee chairmen issued the first subpoena in the impeachment inquiry into President Trump, seeking documents and witnesses regarding his dealings with Ukraine.
articles.lead_paragraph: House Democrats, moving quickly to escalate their impeachment inquiry into President Trump, subpoenaed Secretary of State Mike Pompeo on Friday, demanding that he promptly produce a tranche of documents and a slate of witnesses that could shed light on the president’s attempts to pressure Ukraine to help tarnish a leading political rival.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Fandos and Sheryl Gay Stolberg

articles.headline: Avocado Toast, Meet Gene Editing
articles.snippet: Scientists in the U.S. and Mexico have mapped the DNA of several varieties, work that could help the fruit survive the effects of climate change.
articles.abstract: Scientists in the U.S. and Mexico have mapped the DNA of several varieties, work that could help the fruit survive the effects of climate change.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the early 1990s, a young Australian chef named Bill Granger had a bright idea: Why not spread avocado on toast?

articles.headline: Judge Blocks Trump Administration Plan to Detain Migrant Children
articles.snippet: A federal judge issued a final order that prevents the government from enacting its plan to detain children for lengthy periods.
articles.abstract: A federal judge issued a final order that prevents the government from enacting its plan to detain children for lengthy periods.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — A federal judge on Friday rejected new regulations that would allow the government to hold children and their parents in detention for indefinite periods, one of the Trump administration’s signature efforts to curtail the large number of families arriving from Central America.

articles.headline: Kurt Volker, Trump’s Envoy for Ukraine, Resigns
articles.snippet: House leaders announced on Friday that they would interview Mr. Volker in a deposition next week in connection to their impeachment inquiry.
articles.abstract: House leaders announced on Friday that they would interview Mr. Volker in a deposition next week in connection to their impeachment inquiry.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Kurt D. Volker, the State Department’s special envoy for Ukraine who got caught in the middle of the pressure campaign by President Trump and his lawyer, Rudolph W. Giuliani, to find damaging information about Democrats, abruptly resigned his post on Friday.

articles.headline: White House Weighs Blocking Chinese Companies From U.S. Exchanges
articles.snippet: The proposal, which is in its early stages, would ratchet up tension ahead of trade talks next month.
articles.abstract: The proposal, which is in its early stages, would ratchet up tension ahead of trade talks next month.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration is discussing whether to block Chinese companies from listing shares on American stock exchanges, the latest push to try to sever economic ties between the United States and China, according to people familiar with the deliberations.
articles.byline: By Alan Rappeport and Ana Swanson

articles.headline: C.E.O.s Are Not Here to Save Us
articles.snippet: Their message was inspired. Their returns, not so much.
articles.abstract: Their message was inspired. Their returns, not so much.
articles.lead_paragraph: One wanted to “elevate the world’s consciousness.”

articles.headline: How a Tuxedoed Sommelier Wound Up Homeless in California
articles.snippet: As life unraveled, a skilled wine steward joined the swelling ranks of homeless people in tents across the San Francisco Bay Area.
articles.abstract: As life unraveled, a skilled wine steward joined the swelling ranks of homeless people in tents across the San Francisco Bay Area.
articles.lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — Opus One, Château Lynch-Bages or Petrus. The crimson ribbons of fine wine trickled delicately into his customers’ bulbous crystal glasses.

articles.headline: Democrats’ 2020 Campaign Message: Not Impeachment, They Insist
articles.snippet: The party is bracing for a pitched battle with President Trump that will likely overshadow its policy agenda. But Democrats say they do not want impeachment to dominate the election.
articles.abstract: The party is bracing for a pitched battle with President Trump that will likely overshadow its policy agenda. But Democrats say they do not want impeachment to dominate the election.
articles.lead_paragraph: After the 2016 election, Democratic leaders reached an all but unanimous conclusion: To defeat President Trump in 2020, they would have to do more than condemn his offensive behavior and far-right ideology, as Hillary Clinton had done. They would need, above all, to promote a clear and exciting agenda of their own.
articles.byline: By Alexander Burns and Nick Corasaniti

articles.headline: Impeachment Battle to Turn for First Time on a President’s Ties to a Foreign Country
articles.snippet: To the founding fathers, foreign influence on an American president was an abiding fear and a basis for impeachment.
articles.abstract: To the founding fathers, foreign influence on an American president was an abiding fear and a basis for impeachment.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Alexander Hamilton, as usual, got right to the heart of the matter. When the framers were designing the Constitution and its power of impeachment, one of the high crimes they had in mind was giving into what Hamilton called “the desire in foreign powers to gain an improper ascendant in our councils.”

articles.headline: Tanks, Missiles and No Pigeons: China to Celebrate 70th Birthday of the People’s Republic
articles.snippet: China’s leader, Xi Jinping, will use a military parade commemorating the 70th anniversary of Communist rule to highlight his power in the face of rising challenges.
articles.abstract: China’s leader, Xi Jinping, will use a military parade commemorating the 70th anniversary of Communist rule to highlight his power in the face of rising challenges.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Enormous flower arrangements in Beijing extol the signature promise of China’s leader to realize the Chinese Dream. Red banners urge people to “rally closer” to the Communist Party with “Comrade Xi Jinping at its core.” The authorities have restricted live entertainment venues, ordered people to vacate apartments and banned flying kites, sky lanterns and even homing pigeons, a charming feature of many neighborhoods.

articles.headline: How a Shadow Foreign Policy in Ukraine Prompted an Impeachment Inquiry
articles.snippet: Details of the push by President Trump and Rudolph Giuliani for Ukraine to investigate Democrats show a sustained effort that encompassed elections in both countries.
articles.abstract: Details of the push by President Trump and Rudolph Giuliani for Ukraine to investigate Democrats show a sustained effort that encompassed elections in both countries.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Petro O. Poroshenko was still the president of Ukraine earlier this year when his team sought a lifeline. With the polls showing him in clear danger of losing his re-election campaign, some of his associates, eager to hold on to their own jobs and influence, took steps that could have yielded a signal of public support from a vital ally: President Trump.
articles.byline: By Kenneth P. Vogel, Andrew E. Kramer and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: Ahead of 2020, Facebook Falls Short on Plan to Share Data on Disinformation
articles.snippet: The social network says it has struggled to get the information to researchers because it also wants to protect its users’ privacy.
articles.abstract: The social network says it has struggled to get the information to researchers because it also wants to protect its users’ privacy.
articles.lead_paragraph: In April 2018, Mark Zuckerberg, Facebook’s chief executive, told Congress about an ambitious plan to share huge amounts of posts, links and other user data with researchers around the world so that they could study and flag disinformation on the site.

articles.headline: Trump Was Repeatedly Warned That Ukraine Conspiracy Theory Was ‘Completely Debunked’
articles.snippet: Thomas P. Bossert, President Trump’s first homeland security adviser, said he was “deeply disturbed” that Mr. Trump had urged Ukraine to investigate Democrats.
articles.abstract: Thomas P. Bossert, President Trump’s first homeland security adviser, said he was “deeply disturbed” that Mr. Trump had urged Ukraine to investigate Democrats.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump was repeatedly warned by his own staff that the Ukraine conspiracy theory that he and his lawyer were pursuing was “completely debunked” long before the president pressed Ukraine this summer to investigate his Democratic rivals, a former top adviser said on Sunday.
articles.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg, Maggie Haberman and Peter Baker

articles.headline: Desperate Migrants on the Border: ‘I Should Just Swim Across’
articles.snippet: A growing number of migrants, blocked at the border by new immigration policies, are using riskier tactics to get in.
articles.abstract: A growing number of migrants, blocked at the border by new immigration policies, are using riskier tactics to get in.
articles.lead_paragraph: MATAMOROS, Mexico — Peering out over the Rio Grande, separated from Brownsville, Tex., by only about 100 feet of coursing water, Ana Galeano Valdez talked herself down from a perilous decision — something she has done several times in the weeks she has been living in a tent in one of Mexico’s most dangerous cities.
articles.byline: By Caitlin Dickerson and Lynsey Addario

articles.headline: California’s Latest Wildfire Problem: Insuring the Tree Trimmers
articles.snippet: Contractors crucial to clearing vegetation around power lines face higher coverage costs because of potential liability in later disasters.
articles.abstract: Contractors crucial to clearing vegetation around power lines face higher coverage costs because of potential liability in later disasters.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARADISE, Calif. — D.J. Gomes and his logging crew were working in California’s wine country last fall, helping clear vegetation away from power lines and reduce the ever-growing wildfire risk. While they were gone, fire came for their hometown.

articles.headline: Back Home, House Democrats Tread Carefully on Impeachment and 2020
articles.snippet: A tricky balancing act is underway for Democrats in battleground districts: protecting political gains from 2018 while selling voters on an inquiry into the president.
articles.abstract: A tricky balancing act is underway for Democrats in battleground districts: protecting political gains from 2018 while selling voters on an inquiry into the president.
articles.lead_paragraph: ANAHEIM, Calif. — Orange County was the epicenter of the 2018 House Democratic takeover, where Republicans lost four seats in what was once the heart of Ronald Reagan conservatism in California. On Saturday night, as three of the victorious Democrats were honored at an annual political dinner, a new battle was on everyone’s minds: How to protect those gains in 2020 by selling voters on the impeachment inquiry of President Trump.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin and Catie Edmondson

articles.headline: The New York Fed Chief Is Facing His Biggest Test. Here’s His Response.
articles.snippet: The Federal Reserve Bank of New York president, a top economist, has been criticized for his bank’s response to turmoil in the repo market.
articles.abstract: The Federal Reserve Bank of New York president, a top economist, has been criticized for his bank’s response to turmoil in the repo market.
articles.lead_paragraph: John C. Williams, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, has spent the past two weeks grappling with the regional bank’s most tumultuous period in years.

articles.headline: Hong Kong’s Status as Neutral Ground at Risk as China Asserts Power
articles.snippet: The territory’s traditional role as a gateway is under assault from President Trump’s trade war and a crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators.
articles.abstract: The territory’s traditional role as a gateway is under assault from President Trump’s trade war and a crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a part of the world familiar with conflict, dislocation and ruthless ideological extremism, Hong Kong has long beckoned as an oasis of stability.
articles.byline: By Peter S. Goodman and Austin Ramzy

articles.headline: Forever 21 Bankruptcy Signals a Shift in Consumer Tastes
articles.snippet: The retailer fell victim to the eroding power of shopping malls and said it would cease operations in 40 countries and close up to 178 stores in the U.S.
articles.abstract: The retailer fell victim to the eroding power of shopping malls and said it would cease operations in 40 countries and close up to 178 stores in the U.S.
articles.lead_paragraph: Forever 21, the California retailer that helped popularize fast fashion in the United States with its bustling stores and $5 tops, said on Sunday night that it would file for bankruptcy, a sign of the eroding power of shopping malls and the shifting tastes of young consumers.

articles.headline: Gems, Warlords and Mercenaries: Russia’s Playbook in Central African Republic
articles.snippet: After meddling in the 2016 American election, Russia is using similar tactics in the Central African Republic. But as it sows political chaos, this time it is also seeking diamonds.
articles.abstract: After meddling in the 2016 American election, Russia is using similar tactics in the Central African Republic. But as it sows political chaos, this time it is also seeking diamonds.
articles.lead_paragraph: BANGUI, Central African Republic — The dealer pulled back a shiny pink curtain and sprinkled the contents of two white envelopes across his desk: sparkling diamonds, more than 100 of them.

articles.headline: China Plays ‘Fight the Landlord’ to Tame Hong Kong
articles.snippet: State media puts pressure on Li Ka-shing, a powerful property tycoon, showing the Communist Party’s view of business as a means of control.
articles.abstract: State media puts pressure on Li Ka-shing, a powerful property tycoon, showing the Communist Party’s view of business as a means of control.
articles.lead_paragraph: “Fight the Landlord” is one of the most popular card games in China. The name comes from the 1950s, when the Chinese Communist Party confiscated property from landowners, often violently, in the name of the masses. As many as two million people were killed.

articles.headline: Xi Extols China’s ‘Red’ Heritage in a Land Haunted by Famine Under Mao
articles.snippet: Seventy years after Mao founded the People’s Republic, Xi Jinping visited Xinyang to rekindle revolutionary traditions. Its survivors of mass starvation went unmentioned.
articles.abstract: Seventy years after Mao founded the People’s Republic, Xi Jinping visited Xinyang to rekindle revolutionary traditions. Its survivors of mass starvation went unmentioned.
articles.lead_paragraph: XINYANG, China — Harrowing memories of China’s revolutionary past hang over the rolling wheat fields and scattered villages where the Communist Party’s leader, Xi Jinping, recently visited to commemorate 70 years since Mao Zedong founded the People’s Republic.

articles.headline: New York vs. Grubhub
articles.snippet: Restaurant owners say Grubhub’s business model has cut into their profit margins. A New York City Council committee is investigating.
articles.abstract: Restaurant owners say Grubhub’s business model has cut into their profit margins. A New York City Council committee is investigating.
articles.lead_paragraph: Seamless, the food delivery service started two decades ago in Midtown Manhattan, calls itself “the most New York app in New York.” In advertisements, the company cracks jokes about the L train and takes unsubtle jabs at New Jersey. “Eat Like a True New Yorker,” one subway ad declares.

articles.headline: Japan Raises Taxes on Its Spenders Despite Growth Worries
articles.snippet: The increase, to 10 percent from 8 percent on a wide array of goods and services, will hit consumers who have helped sustain the Japanese economy.
articles.abstract: The increase, to 10 percent from 8 percent on a wide array of goods and services, will hit consumers who have helped sustain the Japanese economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Yasuo Sugiuchi can’t avoid death, but he knew that — if he hurried — he would be able to escape taxes.
articles.byline: By Eimi Yamamitsu, Makiko Inoue, Hisako Ueno and Ben Dooley
